111.content:
To be honest, it just feels good to have a job, I thought to myself. So many of my fellow journalism grads were still living in their parents' basements. And yeah, I'd applied to some bigger papers and was shot down, so what. The Stepford Gazette, or whatever this rag is called, will be a nice stepping stone.

People described me as a young 22. I have no idea what that means besides older, gruffer men treating me like a kid, older, single women acting all cougar-y on me, and women my own age finding me fairly irresistible. I have dark hair and what some have called a cocky grin. I'm on the short side for a guy, and am almost painfully thin. For the most part I dress like a hipster I suppose, in skinny jeans and plaid shirts, with expensive shoes and a fondness for books.

It was quaint, the town. Not terribly small but pretty in a small town way. I had no idea how they had enough news to print a paper, but whatever, they had hired me so I wasn't complaining. I'd heard the paper was rather new, like brand new, so I wondered if there were other new hires here like myself. Hopefully my same age. Always nice to move to a new area and find some friends right away. And maybe some females, you never know. Ashley and I were technically only on a break, but its not like she had agreed to move out here with me. Needless to say I wouldn't be turning any dates down, that's for sure. No such thing as cheating in a different zipcode and all that.

As I drove through the 'downtown' area I spotted the 3 story building where the paper was located. I wondered if I should go straight to the apartment building they had set me up in, just a few short blocks away, or the office first. There was a nice looking diner down the street, too. Maybe a bite to eat before either one?
111.title: Entering Stepford

1111.content:
The office was a low-slung rather suburban looking affair. If it hadn't been for the sign outside, people might have been able to mistake it for just another single-level ranch in suburbia. Birds chirped, the sun was high and the air was remarkably clean. A testament to the fact nobody in this town seemed to drive much of anywhere, preferring instead to walk or jog, ride a bike. As a consequence, there were seemingly few people in town who might be described as fat.

In the driveway, though, is a rather nice old Aston Martin. If there were any Bond aficionados present, they might recognize it as the DB5 from Goldfinger.

As you walk in, you see a pretty, young secretary. VERY pretty...sexy even. Long blonde hair arranged in a loose bun behind her head with an excellent display of cleavage on perfect E cupped breasts if they were an inch. She smiles and nods at you, "You must be one of the new hires. What's your name, please, sir?" She whizzes through a bunch of screens on her very impressive desktop. For such a bucolic town, you almost might have expected them to still be using pen and paper!

"Name?"
1111.title: Hit up the Office

11112.content:
I saunter in the front door of the paper looking to immediately wow these provincial hicks with my Ivy league University book learning when I'm struck dumb by something I hadn't expected to see in these parts, not in a million years.

A blond bombshell is sitting at reception, a woman every bit as sexy as you'd find in a big city. Usually these kinds of women flee far and fast from towns like Stepford. What was she doing here? Besides handling her job with calm reserve, which I have to admit made her that much sexier. She inquires after my name and as easy a question as that sounds, it momentarily defeats me.

My eyes wander down from her pretty face to a stupefying amount of cleavage. My internal bullshit detector was thinking 'Those have got to be fake' when I remember out here these girls are raised on milk and butter and lord does that do a body good. As my mind is memorizing every scrap of decolletage it is also involuntarily comparing what I'm seeing to the girl I left behind.

Ashley is a lovely girl, sweet and naive, devoted, the whole nine. She's also an A cup on a good day. I'd gotten into plenty of arguments with her after not clearing my internet search queries, Ashley having found certain sites with certain how shall we say well endowed individuals. "Why do you like me if these are the kinds of women you're pleasuring yourself to?" she had scolded me, making the word pleasure sound like something you'd find rotting on the side of the road.

The blond asks me my name yet again.

"Paige. Paige Lauren."

Paige starts to feel a bit flustered but he certainly isn't going to show her that. "Well that just goes to show I'm one of a kind dear." he replies, keeping his cool.

At this, Jennifer gives him a knowing wink. "That you are. Anyway, here's my number, maybe you can give me a call sometime and we could get together." she says as she writes her personal number down on the back of one of her business cards and hands it to him. "And the boss, Mr. Weathers, is expecting you for the interview." she replies.

That's when Paige remembers exactly why he came here in the first place. "Oh right, I can't believe I forgot that. What time do you get off work, I could give you a call then?" he asks.

"5 o'clock." she says.

"It's a date then." Paige replies as he starts heading towards the elevators.

1111211.content:
Things were going very well for Paige today. He already had the number of a beautiful girl on a business card in his back pocket and a tentative date with that very same girl after work. Not bad for only just arriving in Stepford.

The interview with Old Man Weathers was a mere formality. Paige had the job, but everyone had to get the old man's nod of approval. Basically, if he didn't come off as some drooling mongoloid, the job was still his. Oh, and he'd get his assignment of course.

Old Man Weathers looked to be roughly 1,000 years old. Everything about him was old and wrinkly, his skin, his suit, even his hair had a kind of crimp to it, what little remained. Only his eyes defied his age, they were bright and lively as if he knew something everyone else did not.

"Welcome, Mr. Lauren! Glad to have you aboard!," the old man stood. Even with a stoop he was taller than Paige.

"Good to meet you too, sir," Paige said.

"Now now, none of that Sir stuff. I may be your boss, I may take home more than you on my paycheck, but I'm also your friend. Call me Rufus," the old man said. "Now I suspect you're eager to hear about what you'll be doing for the Stepford Gazette?"
1111211.title: The Interview

choices: Yeah, sure, no problem, got it, cover girls' sports!

11112111.content:
Weathers leaned back and smiled, raising an eyebrow. "Well, we'll start you off with something easy. Sports beat."

"Of course," he says slowly, thoughtfully, "this won't be your typical sports beat. As I'm sure you've seen, one of the pride and joys of Stepford is our high ratio of female to male residents." He stands and smiles regretfully, "Which means, of course, we have quite a high calibur ladies' sports division at all our schools."

The old man shrugs and smiles, "But if you can make exciting newsprint out of girls' soccer, field hockey and all that then we'll see about placing you on a more taxing assignment." He glances at his watch and raises an eyebrow. A Rolex, natch.

"Now, just a warning to you. The ladies here take their newspapers very seriously. They take their daughters' sports very seriously. Understand?" He raises a bushy eyebrow.
11112111.title: Paige is assigned the Sports beat

111121112.content:
"Mr. Weathers, sir, I don't think you've looked at my resume thoroughly enough," Paige says, getting miffed. "This is the sort of assignment they had us do as sophomores."

Weathers is silent, adopting the position of power in the conversation.

'I mean, I totally respect your experience and everything, but I have a lot to offer this paper. Put me on the hard-hitting stuff! Give somebody else the highschool field hockey post. You won't be disappointed," Paige says.

There is a long pause where, to his credit, Weathers actually looks like he is considering. Then in a devastatingly quiet voice he says, "Of all the impertinent young men to walk through my door, you may be the cockiest yet. There's fire in you, yeah, which won't go to waste here in Stepford, might eventually make some man very happy, but not me."

"Are you firing me, sir?," Paige asks. The 'make some other man happy' line has Paige confused.

"No, not at all. What I am doing is giving you the Sports beat. Like it or lump it. I think you'll find it isn't all that terrible after all," Weathers says. "First game is tonight. Big crosstown rivalry. Varsity Soccer. Be at Winthrop Field at 7:00pm sharp. Copy on my desk at 6:00am. 800 words. Make 'em count."

11112111221.content:
Paige's 'press credentials,' a laughably cheap laminated name-tag, get him right down near the field for the game. He's hungry, and the vendors near the clubhouse selling everything from candy to hot-dogs and popcorn smell great. Yet even though he thinks this is a bum assignment, he gathers his professionalism and refrains from eating. He still wants to make a good impression on the coaches and players and people of Stepford and that means being able to shake hands without having ketchup or butter all over his fingers.

He limits himself to the soda the receptionist gave him.

Its some off-brand kind, locally bottled it turns out. Tasty enough, but there's something not quite right about it. Paige shrugs it off by just assuming he's used to the more familiar taste of name brand Coke. The bubbles tickle his nose. The stuff must be super carbonated because he has to restrain himself from belching. He does his best to ignore the bloated feeling and gathers enough material for his 'silly little assignment.'

By the time the game is over, and the home team was celebrating (even though they had built an unassailable lead by halftime) Paige wasn't hungry any more. His guts still felt very strange, but it wasn't hunger. He wondered whether he should skip the player / coach postgame interviews and go home to rest or stick things out. While he is thinking things over he is surprised to find himself buying and drinking another one of those local sodas.
11112111221.title: You go to the damn game and drink the soda

111121112212.content:
As much as he knows that he has a job to do, no matter how much he hates it, the sickening feeling in the pit of his stomach is getting to be too much to bare and rather than do the postgame interview, he decides to head home and sleep it off.

"Hopefully they'll understand." he says to himself as he gets in his car and leaves the stadium.

He arrives at the apartment he had rented out while living here in Stepford. Once he was inside, he made sure to lock the door behind him which had become a habit since he had that burglary a few years back.

Starting his evening ritual, he went to the refrigerator to grab a soda which of course was that same local drink he had been having since he moved in. With that in hand, he headed towards his favorite chair to catch up on the news.

But when he was watching it, he noticed the screen seemed to flash a bit, making him feel dizzy as his head began spinning. He took one last sip of his soda before he completely fell asleep in his chair as the TV continued running.

Paige takes a seat just outside a room the town Doc has commandeered for today's physicals on the new hires. The door opens and out walks Brian James, you recognize him from yesterday's orientation. "What an odd Doc," Brian says in passing. "He seemed oddly disappointed in my 'robust masculine health.' Told me I was 'unusual' and that 'He was surprised I got hired here in Stepford.' Paige walks in and meets the Doc, Dr. Reynolds. He is tall and thin with a gray mustache. "Ah, Mr... Lauren," he says, pulling out a chart. "You look... disheveled." Is he referring to his already worn suit, or his lack of shower? His fitful sleep?

"I'm fine. let's just get this over with," Paige says. Reynolds starts with height and weight.

"5' 5 and 3/4 inches. And 149 pounds. You're a compact man, Mr. Lauren," Reynolds says.

"That can't be right. I topped out at 5' 7" in the 8th grade. And I haven't weighed less than 150 since I was a teenager," Paige says.

"Well, our measurements do tend to be a bit on the conservative side. If that's what you say I'm sure it's so," Reynolds says not correcting what he wrote.

The rest of the physical is pretty typical. Paige put on a gown and the doc listens to his heartbeat and lungs. Took his blood pressure ("Wonderfully calm") but did spend a lot of time prodding his lower belly and telling him to cough. Reynolds was particularly fastidious when checking his genitals ("Just checking for tumors.")

"Well Mr. Lauren, I can see why the Gazette hired you. You're an ideal specimen for, er, you'll be quite at home here in Stepford. Now get dressed and run along to the shrink, just down the hall," Reynolds says, smiling and ticking off boxes on his chart.
